newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine unions say to go ahead with strike.
newsitem.headline: Argentine unions say to go ahead with strike.

text.p: The secretary general of Argentina's labor confederation CGT said Thursday that an imminent 36-hour general strike and demonstration was a non-negotiable decision by the country's labor movement.

"We will go ahead with the strike. That will not be negotiated. It will not be negotiated," Gerardo Martinez shouted during the opening speech of a union summit to decide on a new CGT chief and set the date for the walkout.
"We are the ones who are right. There is no economic recovery and growth. There is more poverty. That is why we need the unity of the labor movement," he said.

The labor movement has shown profound divisions in past years. The largest CGT confederation had sided with President Carlos Menem's economic reforms, while many unions rallied around two splinter labor groups, the CTA and the MTA.
With 17.1 percent unemployment, the entire labor movement held a successful general strike August 8 to protest belt-tightening measures launched by former Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo.

After his successor, Roque Fernandez, confirmed he would continue with the reforms and announced his own set of austerity measures, the unions said they would continue their "fight" with another walkout expected later this month.
Menem called on the unions Thursday to negotiate a solution and said that the strike would hurt all Argentines and that would be a sign of "lack of solidarity."
